The police is employed by a city to protect the interest of the corporation 
(city). The supreme court has found many times, that police has no 
obligation to protect an individual.

The Sheriff is elected, and for that he has to present himself during an 
election. The Sheriff is the law, not above the law. He is bound by his 
oath to uphold the constitution, which naturally sets limits for him, too. 
The reason why a Sheriff is not a politician in todays common understanding 
of the word, is the fact that he is not depended or bound by a political 
party. Being associated with a party is different.
A politicians career depends on party loyalty. A Sheriffs career depends of 
loyalty to the people. That's why the Sheriff is so important.

Police brutality is almost always an issue of police, and to a way lesser 
extent of a Sheriff.

There are places where a Sheriff has to exert all his authority to stay on 
top of things, e.g. Maricopa country, AZ, but there it is seen as 
appropriate as evidenced by continuous reelection of the Sheriff. In other 
towns the priority is to make sure nobody is bothered. The Sheriff of 
Beaver, UT is known for watching peoples back and make sure, they can go 
unhindered about their business.

If a Sheriff fails to meet the definition of appropriate, he won't be 
reelected. If the police fails, nothing happens and politics moves on with 
business as usual.

The many initiatives against police brutality in San Diego show how easily 
police can get out of hand and fail to meet peoples need for law and order, 
and the inability of the people to just fire the Head of police. Somebody 
should tell them to fire their boss, the major. this of course could cause 
a serious conflict of interest on many levels.

+WDEMMEL First off, I'm sure you meant "County" as opposed to "Country", 
but that's neither here nor there. Even the Sheriff is answerable to "the

    I don't know where you are, but here(San Diego), the sheriffs office 
only patrols unincorporated areas or a city that does not have its own 
department. They also run the jails, sometimes serve eviction orders, staff 
the courts and not much else. They do far less in our county as opposed to 
others where they may patrol all of it. Here, we're more concerned about or 
police chiefs as opposed to the Sheriff. It's very rare to see a deputy out 
on the streets. Just sayin'. Let us remember that Sheriffs run for 
election. So while they be a law enforcement officer, they are also a 
politician. A politician that gives his/her word is an oxymoron. Thanks for 
the comment though.

+chris b The Sheriff is the law, empowered directly by the People. He has 
to answer to nobody in his county, other than to the people. His authority 
comes from the trust and respect the people have in his judgement to 
fulfill his promise to uphold the constitution and protect the peoples 
rights. This far reaching power allow a Sheriff to do what is appropriate 
in his country, which leads to reelection if handles properly, or 
replacement if the needs of the community are not meet. That's why there 
are countries, where the Sheriff's action is see very controversial from 
outside the county, but the Sheriff enjoys the highest level of respect 
inside the county and is elected with a strong majority time and again.

Nothing contributes to the quality of life more that a Sheriff that upholds 
his oath and protects your rights, in a manner that is appropriate for your 
county. You have no stronger representation for your rights than the 
Sheriff of your county. So, be mindful, to elect a Sheriff, who gives you 
his word to uphold the constitution.

In most states, the sheriff is a constitutional officer, meaning that 
counties must have a sheriff. The office may be largely ceremonial, with 
some duties to serve papers and provide security for the courts. In other 
states, the sheriff does these things and also runs the county jail. In 
most states, the sheriff does all of these, and also provides general law 
enforcement services to unincorporated areas of the county and some cities 
that do not have their own police, and contract to the sheriff to provide 
police services. 
A few counties have both a sheriff's department (also called a sheriff's 
office--the names are more or less interchangeable) and a county police 
department. This usually comes about when the county government doesn't 
want to have a chief law enforcement officer they can't fire at will. The 
county police department has a chief of police, who reports to the county 
commission and serves at their pleasure. Where this happens, the county 
sheriff is relegated to running the jail and serving legal process. 
Line employees of a sheriff's department are called deputies or deputy 
sheriffs. They generally have the same law enforcement powers as a police 
officer. Now you be the judge and tell me which law enforcement in this 
video was in the right and which one wasn't.﻿
